source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: Small azimuthal temperature differences on the cladding tube cause a relatively homogeneous decrease of the cladding tube wall thickness along the circumference and, consequently, lead to relatively large burst strains; large azimuthal temperature differences occurring in the course of deformation lead to a preferred reduction in wall thickness on the hot part only of the cladding tube circumference and hence to relatively low burst strains

evidence_span: The extent of oxidation stays within the $1 7 \%$ limit of the ECC criteria even after extended preoxidation and transient exposure at maximum temperature ( $1 0 \  \mathrm { m i n }$ $1 2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } )$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The circumferential burst strain of the cladding is kept relatively small due to temperature differences on the cladding circumference.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The cooling effect of the ECCS increases temperature differences on the cladding tube circumference and limits in this way the mean circumferential average burst strains in bundles to values around $50 \%$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: Unidirectional coolant flow during the refilling and reflooding phases results in the highest possible flow blockage of approximately $70 \%$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: Thermal-hydraulic analyses of the emergency core cooling by pessimistic evaluation models show that in a PWR the majority of the fuel rods reach peak cladding temperatures lower than ${ 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ and that only the relatively few high-rated fuel rods which represent less than $1 \%$ in the whole reactor core attain peak cladding temperatures of approximately $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: Thermal-hydraulic analyses of the emergency core cooling by pessimistic evaluation models show that in a PWR the majority of the fuel rods reach peak cladding temperatures lower than ${ 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ and that only the relatively few high-rated fuel rods which represent less than $1 \%$ in the whole reactor core attain peak cladding temperatures of approximately $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The percentage of fuel rods with peak cladding temperatures above ${ \bf 8 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ is less than $1 0 \%$ .
